tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This psalm is a song of praise.
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"

tn.ref: A psalm. A song of David
tn.text: "This is a psalm that David wrote"

tn.ref: For you, God in Zion, our praise waits
tn.text: This speaks of praise as if it were a person who could act on its own. AT: "To you alone, God in Zion, we will offer our praise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: our vows will be carried out to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "we will do what we have promised you that we would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
David speaks about iniquity as if it were a person that is able to defeat or oppress. AT: "It is as if our own sins were defeating us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The word "them" refers to our "iniquities."
The words "you" and "your" in this verse refer to Yahweh.
This does not mean that the man actually lives in the temple but that he is there very frequently to worship Yahweh. AT: "worship often in your courts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: We will be satisfied with the goodness of your house, your holy temple
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The goodness of your house, your holy temple, will satisfy us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "we" refers to David and the people he is speaking to. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
"your house, which is your holy temple"
"Because you are righteous"
"you are"

tn.ref: of all the ends of the earth ... across the sea
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meanings. AT: "of all the people who live throughout the earth and across the sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: of all the ends of the earth
tn.text: This refers to the people who live all over the earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: you who are belted with strength
tn.text: The writer speaks of God as if he wore his strength like a belt. AT: "showing that you are very powerful" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the roaring of the seas, the roaring of their waves
tn.text: These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to create a vivid impression on the hearer or reader. AT: "the continuous roaring of the seas" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a loud noise caused by the wind and waves
The implied word "quiet" can be added to the translation. AT: "and quiet the commotion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
loud noise
proof or something that shows that another thing is true

tn.ref: you make the east and the west rejoice
tn.text: The phrase "the east and the west" refers to the people who live all over the earth. AT: "you cause people everywhere to shout joyfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
This refers to the soil of the earth.
"you make the soil very good so that good things will grow in it"

tn.ref: the river of God is full of water
tn.text: This refers to the supply of water in the sky that God sends to water the earth and fill the streams. AT: "you fill the streams with water" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The words "You" and "your" refer to Yahweh.
"the earth's furrows"
A furrow is a long narrow trench made in the ground for planting seeds or for watering the field where grains have been planted.
edges

tn.ref: You crown the year with your goodness
tn.text: Here the "year" is given the human quality of wearing a crown. AT: "You have honored the year with a good harvest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: drop fatness down to the earth
tn.text: The word "fatness" suggests fertility or goodness. As used in this phrase, it points to how Yahweh makes the soil so good and fertile that it produces abundant harvest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
There is so much dew in the pastures that they are said to drip with it. AT: "The pastures ... are full of dew" or "Much dew drips in the pastures of the wilderness"

tn.ref: the hills are clothed with joy
tn.text: The writer speaks of the beauty of the hills as if they were joyful people, and of joy as if it were clothing.  AT: "the hills are like people wearing joy" and "the hills are like joyful people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The pastures are clothed with flocks
tn.text: The writer speaks of the pastures as being so covered with flocks that it is like the pastures are wearing a garment.
a large field where animals feed on the grass
group of animals, such as sheep and goats

tn.ref: they shout for joy, and they sing
tn.text: The pastures, hills and valleys are so bountiful, that they seem to shout and sing for joy. AT: "they are like joyful singing people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The word "they" refers to the pastures and valleys.
